headline: Tasty Collard Greens
description: This recipe for Southern collard greens with smoked turkey is a classic Thanksgiving favorite. Crushed red pepper flakes add a spicy kick!

video.description: See how to make classic collard greens with a little spicy kick.
video.name: Tasty Collard Greens

name: Tasty Collard Greens
recipeIngredient: 5 bunches collard greens - rinsed, trimmed and chopped
salt and black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add garlic; gently sauté until fragrant and golden brown, about 1 minute. Pour in chicken stock and add turkey leg; cover and simmer for 30 minutes.
Add collard greens and increase heat to medium-high. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally, until greens have cooked down, about 45 minutes.
Reduce heat to medium. Season with salt and pepper to taste; cover and continue to cook until greens are tender and dark green, 45 to 60 minutes.
Drain greens, reserving cooking liquid. Mix in red pepper flakes if desired. Use reserved cooking liquid to reheat leftovers.

review.reviewBody: This is the first time I've made collard greens from scratch - fresh out of our garden - and I must say, this recipe is simply amazing! My only changes: I added 1 medium chopped onion, 2 cups of white wine, a bit more chicken broth (I just used 2 32-oz boxes), and 2 bay leaves to simmer the turkey leg. For those having issues with insufficient liquid, I would recommend bringing everything but the greens to a boil in a large pot, covering the pot tightly, and reducing the heat to the very lowest of simmers (just the few occasional bubbles). I simmered the leg that way for a good 4+ hours until the meat was falling off the bone. Remove the bones, skin, gristle, and shred the remaining leg meat. Then add the chopped collard greens, cover the pot tightly again, and simmer at the same low setting for 2+ hours or until they are tender. You will have plenty of savory juices to enjoy with the greens until they are gone. Serve with a nice pat of butter on top (and a little Lawrey's Seasoned Salt, if you so choose). We served ours with a steamed sweet potato with home made tahini sauce - lovely! I would make this recipe again in a heartbeat.
Great recipe with amazing flavor!
Love it! I’m from Louisiana and love my soul food!

So good!! Next time gonna use a smoked turkey leg but the flavor on thos was wonderful. 

Used more garlic and onions and omitted chili flakes.

Very tasty!
I added 2 leeks and doubled the garlic. Also cooked it about an hour longer. Delicious!!

This was great! I didn’t have easy access to a cooked turkey leg, so I used turkey sausage. It was delish and felt very authentic. I grew up eating collards in the south. My not thing is when we were done, I had to add water to the broth to make a good potlikker. If you love potlikker, you’ll definitely need to do that.

Loved it!

 Forgot to crosscut the greens during preparation, but caught and rectified it as I was putting the into the pot..

Had to add an additional cup of chicken stock and still there was maybe a little more than a cup left at the end.

This was great! Simple to do and if you add two Turkey drums, you can make it into a light dinner for two. I also added about 6 large baby portabello mushrooms sliced and 2 small yellow onions sliced (they were added in the second half of the recipe where it tells you to add the collards. Onions placed in first on too if the already cooking Turkey legs, then the collards and the mushrooms on top. Then stir occasionally as directed). This was super tasty! Also I used better then bullion chicken broth, so no need to add any seasonings, it was perfect. You could easily make this into a soup as well.
Came out perfect, very tasty.
Been trying to get that "flavor" I remember fro a while- who knew it was chicken flavor! Now I can make these more often and with my newfound confidence, bring to covered dish events!
Really good. I added garlic & onion powder and a few tablespoons of ACV.
Easy and delicious.
wow, this is awesome, thank you for share. Jersey girl who married a true southerner. I impressed my hubby and family..thank you
This is the absolute best recipe! I now use it to make my kale too!

First time we have tried Collard Greens this recipes was easy and delicious. I smoked the legs myself in my Green Egg and used two turkey legs with the recipe. I also put red pepper hot sauce in for the perfect tang.
My husband did his thing with making this dish... Delicious! Will definitely have it again .. sooner than later.

Great recipe! Made a couple changes and additions1. Added an onion to the sautéed garlic. (Doubled the garlic)2. Used ham hock instead of turkey leg3. Replaced 2 bunches of collard green with mustard greens and turnip greens. 4. Accidentally added too much salt so threw in a couple potatoes chopped into chunks. They were the best potatoes ever!

Everyone loved these collard greens. Worth the extra time to de-stem the collards. Better flavor (less bitter) and texture. FYI - Recipe doesn't say to keep the collards covered at every step of cooking.
I will definately make this again with a few additions. Because the smoke turkey was not flavorful enough I added Goya dry ham flavor seasoning to the smoked turkey drummets.
Best Greens recipe I have found (close to a family recipe), I do use more stock than it calls for.

I made this exactly as the recipe stated, other than cooking it a little longer as some had suggested. This was soooo good! It was the first time I had made greens and found the recipe to be easy to follow. I made vegetable soup the following day and added about 1 1/2 cups of the greens with its juices to the soup, and OMGOODNESS, it took the soup to another level of deliciousness!

The first time I made collard greens with a turkey leg. This time I made it with an oxtail and it turned out fantastic! Excellent recipe that brought rave reviews from my usually tough critic - my spouse! We loved it!
This is my go to recipe whenever making collard greens. I dice up an onion or two and toss it in when I put the garlic on sauté. ?

Made today as directed with just a pinch of sugar and they came out perfect!!! I never make collards with smoked turkey because I love my smoked neck bones but trying to eat a little healthier. Definitely delish! I only used a pinch of sugar because it's summertime and greens probably a little bitter, but delish all the same. Thanks for sharing!

My Family just loved these greens. Absolutely 
good!!!

My Family just loved these greens. Absolutely 
good!!!

This was very good. I had just a few people to feed so I only used three bunches of greens rather than the five. I also used two smoked ham hocks instead of the turkey leg since I had them on hand. I would make this again.

This was very good. I had just a few people to feed so I only used three bunches of greens rather than the five. I also used two smoked ham hocks instead of the turkey leg since I had them on hand. I would make this again.
Was Excellent, however add 1/4 cup brown sugar in the last 45 minutes and it kill the bitterness.
Absolutely delicious. I followed the recipe except I only used a Tbsp of oil. I also added a small onion.
I didn’t have much liquid left after two rounds of simmering for 45 minutes each, but the greens were delicious. My husband couldn’t wait to eat seconds!

Fellow vegetarian here but I was craving some collard greens. I followed the recipe simply omitting the smoked turkey leg and it still came out fantastic. Delicious and very flavorful. I can see how the smoked turkey leg would add flavor but honestly it’s so good without it too. Great recipe.
Very enjoyable, to make and eat.
I added the addition of a chopped sweet onion. Amazing.
It is delicious! I added 1 15.5 oz can of black eye peas. My husband had 2 bowls of it!
This recipe turned out very well. It was easy to make and delicious. I prepared it for a family dinner and everyone loved it.
this was very delicious. I added a green seasoning that I allowed to simmer. I omitted the meat.
I’m a vegan; so, I used Liquid Smoke instead of turkey leg and vegetable stock instead of chicken.

I like to use what I have so I added cut up yellow, red and white potato in the pot with the collards and leek with the garlic...I added another 4c chicken stock as well. Served as soup with corn bread side. Quite delish!

Fabulous, delicious, healthy!! I followed the recipe exactly and was delighted with how the collards turned out . If I could recommend anything, it would be to use a quality chicken broth. I used a cheap watery one and the flavor was just not the same.
I didn't have a turkey drumstick, so I used a rib steak, but don't leave it cooking the whole time with the greens. I also only added about a half a tablespoon of red pepper and 2T of butter.
Followed this recipe for Easter and the family thought they were awesome. I couldn't find enough collard greens, so I subbed some mustard greens for some of the collards.

i just got finish making these collards greens and they......turned out absolutely DELICIOUS! I made it with two bags of collard greens, followed the directions to a tee. I will make them like this every time. 5 stars!!! LOVE IT!!!
I’ve made collard and turnip greens numerous times. This is a very easy and good recipe for anyone to follow. I particularly love the addition of the red pepper flakes.
Add just about a tablespoon of pickle juice and sherry vinegar

I made this for Thanksgiving and the family loved it. My son asked me to make more so a few days after I made a second batch. Now I am cooking them again for Christmas dinner. They have become my greens go to receipt.
Hands down, the best collards I’ve ever eaten!
Delish. Everyone loved the greens.

I'm not often fooled by AR ratings, but I'm not sure why they are so high for this recipe. If you like greens seasoned by ham hocks, you will be disappointed. The turkey leg added little to no flavor. Healthier? Maybe, but there were plenty of collards left over after the Thanksgiving meal.

I'm not often fooled by AR ratings, but I'm not sure why they are so high for this recipe. If you like greens seasoned by ham hocks, you will be disappointed. The turkey leg added little to no flavor. Healthier? Maybe, but there were plenty of collards left over after the Thanksgiving meal.

They were perfect. I stuck with the tried tested and true ham hock. Instead of adding the red pepper flakes on greens themselves at the end, I adding them in towards the end of the cooking time. My mother is in awe.
I used country ham instead of turkey leg for seasoning and turkey broth instead of chicken broth. There was no need to add salt with the country ham seasoning.
This recipe is truly pot-licking good! Made this for Easter this year. It went great with the ham and some of the richer side
I add one garlic clove, beer rub for meat seasoning, lemon pepper, and chicken meat tenderizer
First time I made greens so I followed the recipe as written. This was very good, easy to make. Definitely a keeper. Thanks for sharing the recipe.
Wonderful flavor! The ENTIRE family LOVED them!
Phenomenal!!!! So good and tasty. Not difficult at all.

this recipe is basically how i've made collards for years, but a couple of important changes will improve upon a pretty good recipe. first, i use smoked turkey wings because the legs have splinter bones in them that can be tough to fish out (and you definitely want to get all of them out because of the potential choking hazard). the wings have just as much flavor as the legs.

an old southern trick from my mother & grandmother is to wash the greens with baking soda and/or some dishwashing liquid. this will help get the grit and sand off the leaves better than just clear water. using a salad spinner helps too.

cook the turkey until it's tender and falling off the bone then discard the skin and debone the wing. also, when you add the collards, make sure you stir them regularly so that you don't end up with some greens that are overcooked while others are under done. collards are tough and take a while to cook, longer than this recipe calls for, but don't leave them completely unattended for more than 10-15 minutes as you may have to add water (the broth may boil down and become salty, so taste it if it's reduced significantly).
This was the best recipe. Helped me step up my game on the greens.
I found that a whole turkey leg made the greens very salty and also you may want to wrap the turkey leg in cheese cloth because I had many small bones in the greens once I served them

This was my first time ever making greens. I didn't use the extra spice and instead of a turkey leg, I used 6 slices of turkey bacon and no added salt. I had someone who doesn't even like greens eat them and love them. Also I had 4 people (3 of whom make awesome greens themselves) try them and they all said nothing needed to be added. I don't eat everyone's greens and have never really loved them, but I'm trying to eat healthier and I loved them too. Great recipe!
I had never made greens before and got RAVE compliments on these.
I love this recipe. I think the chicken stock gives it that good flavor. I tweaked the seasoning a bit, but overall great recipe!

Great recipe! Easy to adjust if you don't have all the ingredients. 
I made a couple of changes and it still turned out tasty.
Thanks!
I ran out of chicken stock and used bullion cubes insread...tasted great.
Add onion, cabbage and used cayenne pepper. It was a great dish.
This was fantastic! Will def make again!
I made these for Thanksgiving and they were so tasty. I was super excited about this because I've never made greens before. I will be making this again.

OK! Now when your home cooking SOUTHERN mother ask you, how you make these greens BECAUSE they taste better than hers, you know you have a winning recipe. I changed NOTHING to this recipe, besides a huge SMILE! The 1st time I cooked these my oh so picky husband refused to be the taster (the one how taste things to see if it needs a little more or a little less) but he even enjoyed them. This 2016 Thanksgiving I was appointed to cook the entire dinner by my lonesome ??. These greens were the last things to be started. Mom even said "the greens smell good". NOW I'm sweating bullets, because I know she's going to talk about me if they didn't taste good ??. But you now know the outcome to that. If you don't have the turkey leg (I used a smoked one) it's okay the recipe is good with or with out and guess what no vinegar needed! ?? Thank You So Much for the recipe, you saved me from a year of shaming!

I used this recipe to make a large pot of collards for Thanksgiving. It was amazing! My son said it's the best collard greens he's ever tasted. Like someone suggested I used the precut greens from Walmart. I was nervous because usually I buy whole collards and cut the leaves off the stalk and then discard the stalk. The Walmart brand has stalk and all. But once I cooked it down, they were tender. While cooking, I did add some vinegar and sugar. Also I cooked on medium low for 3 hours uncovered to get a tender consistency with thorough flavor. This recipe really is as good as everyone else says!

I followed the recipe except I couldn't find a smoked turkey leg. Instead, I used turkey bacon. I also cooked it in the pressure cooker for 17 minutes instead of on the stovetop. It was perfectly cooked and delicious!

My grandmother made VERY good greens & with her being gone now, this has been my go-to recipe for the past few years now. The only thing I did differently is added more seasonings to taste & a few hot peppers w/ some pepper sauce. And I don't drain the juice off the greens b/c it adds more flavor w/ them sitting in it. My family & friends love my greens....
Turned out great! I did not use the red pepper flakes, as I do not like spicy veggies. Will definitely use this recipe again!

This is sooo good! Way better than expected. The collard greens were tender and savory. I used 2 small smoked ham hocks (about 1lb) instead of the turkey leg and it was wonderful. Just follow this recipe and this will be one of your favorite side dishes for Sunday dinners, family pot-lucks and holiday feasts!
Super easy. I used smoked sausage since I didn't have the turkey leg. Kids and wife all said it was delicious

Omg these greens turned out great! I did add chopped onion in with the garlic. I've made greens a couple times before using bacon to flavor them, but using turkey wings gave it soooo much more flavor. This is the way I'm making greens from now on.
Honestly, this is the best recipe for greens I have ever tasted! I cut the amount of oil down, but otherwise use the recipe as is. Simply delicious!!

Easy recipe to follow and so delicious! I used part of a smoked turkey breast I had on hand. I followed the directions except for adding brown sugar as one reader suggested. When I planted my collards in the garden my husband told me how much he disliked them and I would be eating them alone. After one bite of these he changed his mind completely! YUMMM!

Excellent ! Tastes delicious! My only minor complaint is that the first time it was too salty, even though I used reduced salt chicken broth and didnt add any additional salt after the long cooking time it was just too salty for my taste. The second and third time I made my own broth with no salt and it was much better. I make a big batch and then throw the leftovers in smaller portions in the freezer with plenty of the broth and it reheats perfectly!

This is the ONLY recipe I use for Collard Greens. I saw it on this site years ago, and have made it many, many times. The greens always turn out perfect, and my entire family loves them. This is high praise coming from someone who was born and raised in North Carolina! I had a lot of collards over the years, and these are the best.
Made this vegetarian with vegetable broth and creole seasoning. The cook time listed is perfect.

Excellent and very easy recipe. I have made these twice and this is my favorite greens recipe. I haven't used the turkey in them, but bacon is a acceptable substitute. Being a Southern girl, it's hard to find collard recipes that appeal to my tastebuds, this is my go to one. Thanks for sharing.

Delicious. Well worth the time on this one. I have done it with and without the turkey. Both are good but the with turkey gives it an edge. I have saved 30 mins by doing it without the turkey. I just add the greens to the broth mix once it is hot. The greens cone out the same texture.

Every time I make this, I am told they are the best greens anyone has ever tasted. Sometimes I use smoked pork, sometimes I use smoked turkey, just depends on what I find. It doesn't matter, this recipe is so great, everything tastes good.
Amazing! I made this with some leftover ham and added a dash of balsamic vinegar. These were so good! We will definitely use this recipe again!
Didn't change a thing and these were hands down THE best greens I have ever eaten. Making my 3rd batch this afternoon.
This was a-may-zing. Next time I will put less boulleon in it, but otherwise perfect!

Oh my goodness, thank you for this recipe! This was wonderful! I followed the recipe as written, only used 7 cups of chicken broth in case it boiled down too low, which it didn't come close. Then like other reviewers, during the last 90 minutes of cooking I added 2 teaspoons of sugar and one tablespoon of apple cider vinegar. These were not bitter tasting at all. I did not add the peppers at the end because my family doesn't do spicey, but rather served pepper sauce on the table. I saved the liquid to use with leftovers, but there were no left overs!
This dish is okay if eaten right away. Yucky when reheated.

Each time I have used this recipe, it has had an awesome response from my family. I did not change a thing. Someone did suggest using smoked turkey wings and I will give them a try soon.

I tried the smoked turkey wings and they did not do it for me. I have gone back with smoked turkey legs.
For not using pork, these turned out great! Thanks for the recipe.

Make sure the collards are fresh! I used a ham hock instead of turkey leg. Also added a medium chopped onion. You don't "have" to sauté the garlic. Adding one teaspoon of sugar will eliminate any bitterness in the collards (some collards are better than others depending on where they are grown).

When I went to pick up the items for this recipe the store I went to was all out of collard greens so I substituted 3 bunches of mustard greens and 1 bunch of kale for the collard greens. The end result was still fantastic. According to another reviewer's suggestion, I added about 2 tbsps of honey to offset the bitterness of the greens (1 would have been enough for collard greens, but mustard greens are naturally much more bitter). I also added 1 onion. I only made these changes because I used mustard greens, but other reviewer's did the same for their collard greens. I served this as soup and will certainly be making this again. Thanks for sharing :)

This was so good I ate it for breakfast the next day!
I did add onions and garlic. MMmmmmm!!!
This was a excellent recipe and a nice change from ham hocks or just a broth even
This is how I make my collards and I love it! I add in some sliced onion, and have made this with or without pork flavoring, but otherwise, this is a simple and delicious way to cook greens.
This is how I make my collards and I love it! I add in some sliced onion, and have made this with or without pork flavoring, but otherwise, this is a simple and delicious way to cook greens.
this is the best collard greens recipe ever!!! followed the recipe to the t and it came out perfect,will be on my holiday table from know on.
I made without the smoked turkey and it was fantastic! I will definitely make this again.
